Factory_Description:
52 employees and 197 workers when it closed
Considered one of the largest mills in Europe, with its production of 500 quintals of wheat and 250 quitals of pasta per day (page 70)
- Week long strike during 29 April 1919
Salary improvements and limited working hours to 8 hours a day (page 57)
Closing_Reason: Closed after WWII because ships were becomming too large to access the canals and were no longer the main shipping source. Port access was once their main advantage, but became a problem since there were no trains that they could load nearby.

Factory_Description: Large sawmill; constructed the beams for Academia bridge in 1961 (citation 91). Trevisan manufactured wheelbarrows, trolleys and carts of all types. All the carts we see in Venice and on the Lido came out of the factory (Bonfanti, 1930 p. 302)
O_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation 90
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 14, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation 91

English_Name: Casale Monferrato lime and cement factory
Italian_Name: s.a. Fabbrica di calce e cementi di Casale Monferrato
Factory_Description: Lime and cement factory that produced 500 thousand quintals of Portland cement per year. (citation 87) To prepare the cement mixture produced, clay from the lagoon bed and limestone from Istrian rocks were used (Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca)
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca
Closing_Reason: Closed at the onset of WWI.
C_Reason_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca citation number 89

Factory_Description: A long two-story building built in 1909, expanded in 1927-28. The only currently active factory on Giudecca.
O_Date_Source:

Factory_Description: Pila Pilla was a part of a larger factory that was used for the distillation of minerals and asphat purification (citation 83). Pila Pilla was an ad hoc company which produced eletric batteries (of his own invention) which he wanted to allocate to Italian soldiers to safely illuminate their trenches (citation 84). Pila Pilla moved to Florence where it remained even after WWI. After moving to Florence, the factory had changed the name to Superpilla and, finally, Superpila (citation 85).
O_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca citation number 84
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation number 86
Closing_Reason: Relocated: Moved to Florence during the onset of WWI
C_Reason_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 13, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation number 85

Factory_Description: Built in 1902, The first Giudecchino factory in the style of the Stucky (Lando, 2023, p. 12 'Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca') After closing to install safety works, the company changed its name to Societa Birra San Marco in 1908. In the early 20th century, Societa Birra San Marco financed the prizes for rowing regattas (Lando, 2023, p. 3).
O_Date_Source: Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca (Lando, 2023, p. 12) citation 79 https://www.birravenezia.it/storia
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 12 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation number 79, Pietro Lando. Interview, 2024.
Closing_Reason: The owners decide to move the liquor plant elsewhere and moved Biliotti brewery to the Giudecca. The building was temporarily closed to install safety works
C_Reason_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 12 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, citation number 79-80

Factory_Description: Same company as Società Distilleria Veneziana, closed to install safety works and reopened under the name Societa Birra San Marco (Story of Passion). In 1913, the company changed its name to Fabbrica di Birra Venezia SA, or Birra Venezia. Birra Venezia became a successful brand not only in Italy, so much so that an advertising notice, published in the Gazzetta di Venezia of 9 July 1928, even defined it as Supplier of the English Army in Egypt and in second place among the exporting factories Italian (p. 13)
Closing_Reason: Adhering to the concentration policy that began to spread across multiple sectors, Birra Venezia and about ten other brands were absorbed by Birra Pedavena.

Factory_Description: Brewery purchased from Veneziana Beer (Birra Venezia) in the 1930s.
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 46 Gli anni della resa (387)
Closing_Reason: Fell victim to the dark times - industrial decline on the Giudecca
C_Reason_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 46, Gli anni della resa (387)

Factory_Description: Complex of multi-story buildings founded by S. Biagio; built in 1902, expanded 1908-1921 (Stampa: Tipografia Commerciale/Venezia, 1981)
O_Date_Source:
Lando, 2023, p. 31 1918-1940: anche alla Giudecca cambia tutto 
(242)
Closing_Reason: Closed as a result of the declining industrial presence in the Giudecca

Factory_Description: Largest stable in the Giudecca, farm (Lando, 2023, p. 14, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca, (92)), capable of hosting up to 130 cows (Lando, 2023, p. 36, Ancora la guerra, (286)
O_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 14 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca (92)

Factory_Description: Italian film production and distribution company.
Closing_Reason: Overwhelmed by financial difficulties

English_Name: Scarpa di Mario Scarpa & Figli S.n.c.
Factory_Description: Scarpa company, shipyard, in business since the early 1900s, a large part of the construction site is not used, still open in 2024

originally, Naval shipyard, construction site and wood storage, now it is used today for cooperative for piling, boat mooring, etc., production and work cooperative has been transformed into a service cooperative to support the activity carried out by gondoliers, the category of workers who currently use our services the most
A Tannery that was used to shelter evicted people and known by the name of baracon or capanon in the 1920s.
Knitwear factory that is currently the location of SerenDPT, a startup incubator.
Closing_Reason: Large fire.

Factory_Description: Giudecca shipyard, responsible for building boats of different sizes for the lagoon.
Closing_Reason: Liquidation

Factory_Description: former Lucchese area, The Venezia Sviluppo consortium was born from the union of five companies, with complementary activities between them, which managed to renovate a degraded area of ​​half a hectare of surface and 10,000 m3 of buildings owned by the municipality of Venice on the Giudecca to relaunch the shipbuilding industry of quality and above all promote the valorisation of the economy of the lagoon area, The Consorzio Venezia Sviluppo was born in the spacious area, which revives the times of the industrial Giudecca of the last century, together with Chia there are other companies: Pitteri Impimenti, Ammiana engineering studio, Maschio carpentry, Alilaguna. The Consortium is a beautiful synergy between Venetian entrepreneurs to make this area grow. The Chia Shipyard is also a fine example of how the knowledge of the shipwrights passes from generation to generation, today from the Chia family, already in the third generation with their nephew Kevin, to some young Venetians. In addition to the construction of wooden and fiberglass boats, we also specialize in:

Apart of Ammiana SRL, which is a company that deals with Architectural and Urban Planning, event planning and temporary installations, Restoration of the building heritage, Landscape Archaeology, Preliminary verifications of archaeological interest, since 2002 Analysis of territorial transformations, of Structural and Plant Engineering, of Company and construction site safety. Ammiana SRL Engineering founded in 2010 with the main purpose of dealing with the transformation of the disused productive area (former) Lucchese shipyard, on the southern edge of the Giudecca island in Venice.\

Apart of the Consorzio Venezia Sviluppo, 1956 when Giancarlo Chia, after an experience in the legendary Celli shipyard, set up his own business by opening a shipyard in San Pietro di Castello, specialize in the construction and repair of professional and representative boats made of wood and VTR. tender for large yachts. For years our clientele has mainly been made up of taxi drivers and institution

Carpentry shop founded in 1984. Mario Bullo and Alessandro Vianello decided to combine their artisanal skills to take over this historic carpentry shop: Falegnameria Maschio. Since then they have always been available for artisanal work involving wooden works, create a variety of wooden objects kitchens, stairs, tables, chairs, wardrobes, doors and windows, tope, sandoli, bonnets
The Pitteri Impianti company is located in Venice and represents a leading company in the installation, assistance and maintenance of various types of systems, both civil and industrial.

Giudecca shipyard responsible for rearmament works, building dredgers, tugboats, and barges. In 1991, change to 'Gruppo Faldis sas', where they expanded the maintenance service to include pleasure boats, an increasingly expanding sector
Closing_Reason: Declining industry in Venice resulted in less business

Factory_Description: Fertilizer Factory during the late 19th century. Replaced by the Toffolo Naval Shipyard in 1909
Originally called Sola Francesco, it arrived at Giudecca in 1846 from Cannaregi to produce natural fiber ropes, copper and iron cables.

Founded in 1878 by Bussolin; it was one of the companies victimized by the consequences of Caporetto but was reborn on the island with another name, Cossulich and C. In 1922, it the building was sold to Casimiro Gaggio, who renovated and enlarged the space.
Carpet from coconut fibers, created from the Bussolin, named after the first founder's son-in-law. The building burned down in 1961 and the area was repurposed for residential use.
Closing_Reason: Fire.

Factory_Description: Junghans was one of the largest watch factories in the world at its peak. They produced fuzes during World War 2 and closed their doors in 1993.
Closing_Reason: Closed due to cost of housing. People could not afford to live and work. Every house was being rented out to tourists.

Factory_Description: A wheelbarrow factory that was transformed into a large sawmill.

One of the two main industrial factories active from 1940-45. Junghans attempted to have a completely Venetian workforce (majority from Giudecca) with a close community; the company had a basketball team that dominated minor league tournaments in the 1950s, but it was literally the after-work team and the purchase of the players took place by offering them jobs in the factory (Lando, 2023, 70). The complex was placed under surveillance during WWII by 25 german guards and two machine guns.
Brick and Lime Factory that was modelled after the medieval Nordic architectural motifs of the Stucky.
Established in 1922 in the premises of a small metal parts factory of the G. Zanchi e C company.
Used as a kiln to make bricks
Repair and construction of boats
Closing_Reason: Sold to Acnil.

Factory_Description: A building on the river used since 1890 as a workshop for the repair and construction of boats that served as Acnil shipyard from 1905 to 1942.

Complex of several buildings and slipways built in 1906, One of the two particularly active industrial companies suring 1940-45 
Constructed and maintained boats (page 64) 
26 April 1945 fight for liberation occurred, where german soldiers (25) and fascists (7) were captured
Founded in 1930 on an area already used as a bead factory (1860) famous for Elixir di china.
Bead factory
Grain storage Redeemer built in 1846.
Warehouse
Coal Warehouse
In business since the early 1900s it employs around 6 people
Founded in 1924, it was previously used as a rag factory and later as a liquor factory.
In business as of 1981.
Grain warehouse
Multi-storey building used as a tobacco warehouse since 1846, repurposed for the State Archives.
Headquarters of the Subsidary of the State Archieves
Multi-storey building used as grain wearhouse since 1846. Used as a youth hostel in the starting in 1958
Multi-storey building on the Giudecca canal used as a warehouse for the grandees from 1846 to 1930, later transformed and used as a finance barracks.
Shed on the Giudecca canal used as a furnace in 1846 and subsequently as a coal warehouse.
Two story ice factory built in 1906 and enlarged and renovated in 1924. After a readaptation to house a pasta factory, the property is currently abandoned.

English_Name: Michele Zaggia's San Marco Pasta Factory
Factory_Description: Pasta factory built in place of the Tanner ice factory after 1942. Fire destroyed all the machinery inside and damaged the building, leaving 35 people without work.
Set of low buildings, built in the early 1900s. Later used as a foundry by the Toffolo company.

Shipyard, build gondolas since 1884, still in business founded on February 2, 1884 by Domenico Tramontin. After learning the art of building gondolas at the Casal ai Servi boatyard, he went on to make important changes to its form, number 16 on the map COMPANY BUILT A SECOND SHIPYARDA
Closing_Reason: Still in business

Factory_Description: Shipyard that opened in the early 1900s (late 1930s), and was in business as of 1981. Magnanini had 12 emploees in 1981. Closed late 1990s
Closing_Reason: Liquidation

Factory_Description: Oil storage, A Gothic palace used as warehouses in 1846. The garden behind it was occupied by two tanks, but the building has been restored and houses some homes
Grain warehouses, Three sheds perpendicular to the Giudecca canal, used since 1846 as grain warehouses; abandoned as of 1981.

English_Name: Venetian Navigation Company in Vapore Lagoon
Italian_Name: Società Veneta di Navigazione a Vaporé Lagunare
Factory_Description: Established in 1892 on a state-owned area already used as a squero and expanded and renovated in 1922. The construction site, consisting of a large warehouse, a slipway and some warehouses, was active as of 1981.
Artifical Fertilizer company.
Closing_Reason: Forced to move from the island to the mainland due to the smell (Bottenighi).

Italian_Name: Imperial Regio Stabilimento Adriatico dei Cementi Idraulici ed Asfalti
Factory_Description: Bitumen and asphalt factory founded by Salomon Mayer von Rothschild and located a few tens of meters from the Redentore church in San Giacomo.
Mechanical Plant, production of small tonnage boats and dredgers.
Closing_Reason: Elimited to make room for housing.

Factory_Description: Construction and maintenance of hulls and engines.
Closing_Reason: Relocation to Porto Marghera.

Factory_Description: Previous called 'The Moschini and Ivancich company' Prepared and marketed rice, sourced raw materials from Polesine, Romagna and Piedmont, and primarily exported to the Far East (and Argentina after WWI). During the conflict of 1915-18 it was requisitioned for the supply of the army. Lando, 2023, p. 14 'Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca' (94)
O_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 14, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca (94)
C_Date_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 14 Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca (96)
Closing_Reason: The entire factory with its machines was transported to Porto Marghera.
C_Reason_Source: Lando, 2023, p. 14, Da San Biagio a calle dell’Accademia dei nobili: l’Europa industriale alla Giudecca (94)

Factory_Description: Turned urban waste into fertilizer.
right in front of the enormous mill and next to the Maritime Station, stood the large building of the Venetian Cotton Mill erected in 1883
Repair and shipyard, still open today, 68 on the map

Shipyard, inaugurated in the 80s on the island of Giudecca at the Minor Venetian Shipbuilding Consortium, when Stefano Costantini and Roberto Dei Rossi began working there under the guidance of Corrado Costantini known as “Buranello”.
Shipyard and boat repair, still open today
Shipyard, a part of the V.Cereseto company, Large shipyard (Current location - the Hotel Cipriani, 4 on map
